title: Witch trials in the early modern period
summary: Prosecutions for the crime of witchcraft reached a highpoint from 1580 to 1630 during the Counter-Reformation and the European wars of religion, when an estimated 50,000[1][2] people were burned at the stake, of whom roughly 80% were women,[3][4] and most often over the age of 40.[5][6][7][8]
